newsitem.title: GERMANY: Rain blocks last stages of German maize harvest.
newsitem.headline: Rain blocks last stages of German maize harvest.

text.p: Maize harvesting in most parts of Germany has been disrupted by rain and small remaining parts of the 1996 crop may have to be left in the fields, experts said on Thursday.
Field work was nearly impossible over the last seven days on wet soils as a result of rainfall and melting snow, the DWD meteorological institute in Offenbach said in its weekly farm weather report.
Maize harvesting efforts in the west of the country made in spite of the problems caused structural damage to some soils.
"Harvesting may have to be abandoned if it gets too cold and if the quality is too bad," a DWD source said.
A source at the German maize committee DMK said the crop should still be 2.80-2.90 million tonnes compared with 2.40 million in 1995 because of area and yield rises.
But the downside of the high volume, from the farmers' point of view, was price pressure -- farmgate prices were at 250-260 marks, down 30 from last year.
In addition, farmers had to pay high drying costs.
The beet campaign continued, with more than 80 percent of beet now delivered to factories.
Winter grain and rapeseed crops were developing well ahead of dormancy during the winter months.
Winter grain needs frosts around minus five to seven degrees C to prosper in December but can be damaged if temperatures sink below minus 12 for a number of days.

DWD forecast maximum day temperatures of five to eight degrees and selective night frosts in the period to December 11. It recorded three to nine degrees in the previous seven-day period, with some spikes at 13.
